data.title: Enable more non-default warnings
data.body:
Although we've long hat `-Wall` and `-Wextra`, there is more useful warnings:

https://kristerw.blogspot.de/2017/09/useful-gcc-warning-options-not-enabled.html

Which of those should we activate?

data.title: [Windows] Change path separator in generated pxd files
data.body:
A workaround until cython/cython#1912 is addressed and a fix is available.

Summary of the changes
- Both `\` and `/` are valid path separators on Windows. The first one is native and default in python (like most other applications), but requires escaping (even in raw string literals - see referenced cython issue).
- The workaround: replace all instances of the first path separator with the (lesser-used, but still acceptable) second one which works for cython without escaping.

data.title: Consolidate fedora build instructions into a single document
data.body: Addresses #915

data.title: fix scrolling without focus (again)
data.body:
Removed the requirement for the mouse to be focussed in the window because it created problems in two scenarios:

1. Mouse scrolling in windowed mode is basically useless because the mouse has to be exactly on an edge for scrolling.
2. Same for a fullscreen multi monitor setup. At least one edge is unfeasible for mouse scrolling.

data.title: Update Fedora build instructions
data.body:
Our build instructions are for fedora 20, 21 and 22.

The currently supported versions are 25 and 26.

Maybe we manage to unify the document to a `fedora.md` which is hopefully future-proof so we don't need to rename it for each release.

data.title: doubled input handling
Setup CI via Travis CI
data.body:
Travis CI has offering for Mac OS X . Offers free for OpenSource projects.

https://blog.travis-ci.com/2017-09-22-macos-update

data.title: Some HUD textures missing (red cross) when converting from AoE 2 HD
data.body:
# Looks like this:
![openage_2017-09-19_21-52-55_00](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29040/30612833-2a6e2792-9d86-11e7-9fae-11512e28d9ea.png)


# To reproduce:

1. Convert textures from a AoE 2 HD Beta 4.3 (in my case, installed on Windows, but openage is run on Linux).
2. Run openage, generate any game.

data.title: Use binary mode for files in cpp
data.body: Python code already does this, so match the behaviour in CPP.

data.title: Build fails on armv7l: 'hypot' not a member of std
buildsystem: let automoc depend on codegen
data.body:
Fixes #907.

Otherwise build may fail because there's
no known recipe to generate the files.

~~We should maybe tune the codegen target to actually have all the generated files as output, not just the timefile. This now was the easier fix, though.~~
The codegen custom command now knows all its output, but the codegen target still depends on the timefile only, so the command isn't run for every generated source.

data.title: Include other Genie Engine games in Readme
data.body: Fixes #811.

data.title: Suggestion: Tag system
data.body:
### Current system: Classes

- HumanWithBow: **archer**
- HumanOnHorse: **cavarly**
- HumanOnCamel: **cavarly**
- HumanOnHorceWithBow: **cavarly_archer**

### Suggested system: Classes with Multiple Inheritance

- HumanWithBow: [**Archer**]
- HumanOnHorse: [**Cavarly**]
- HumanOnCamel: [**Cavarly**]
- HumanOnHorceWithBow: [**Cavarly**, **Archer**]

### Suggested system: Tags

- HumanWithBow: [**human**, **range**, **archer**, **with_bow**]
- HumanOnHorse: [**human**, **melee**, **cavarly**, **on_horse**]
- HumanOnCamel: [**human**, **melee**, **cavarly**, **on_camel**]
- HumanOnHorceWithBow: [**human**, **range**, **cavarly**, **archer**, **on_horse**]

Thoughts?

data.title: Buildings limits, Resource capacity and more
data.body:
- **Buildings**
  - **cost** check and deduction
  -  **limits** max at single instance, max ever created
    - Player keeps track for each unit type the numbers:
      - **units have**: active 
      - **units had**: active and dead
      - **units pending**: being made
- Player **Resource capacity**
  - **Storage** attribute
- Dynamic resources (first steps)
  - **Resource**: one resource type (e.g wood)
  - **Resources**: set of Resource
  - **ResourceBoundle**: Resource-Amount pairs (created with a Resources)
- **Resource** **decay** and **gather rate multiplier**

EDIT:

- **Resource generator** attribute
  - Tmp logic in idle action
- **ResourceCost** 
  - It can be **constant** or **dynamic** (= function of player)
  - Used in **UnitType** and **ReseachType**

EDIT:

- **ResourceBundle** operations with bundles from different versions of Resources

data.title: Ability improve return information
data.body:
The `Ability` class has a member `can_invoke` which returns `bool`.

In order for the GUI to give correct feedback, the return type must be changed in order to provide information about the reason why it can't be invoked (eg. not enough resources, population limit reached, ...)

data.title: Alias Thread IDs to smaller numbers
data.body:
Anyone else gets this:

![screenshot from 2017-08-30 00-41-55](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6997990/29845641-5a1c2d9c-8d1c-11e7-99ca-6c1828fd75d6.png)

Shouldn't that be T1?

data.title: fix scrolling without focus
data.body:
fixes #871.
this is my fastest pr so far

data.title: Test compilation in debug and release mode
Use Sphinx and Breathe (+Doxygen) for documentation
data.body:
Currently, we have Doxygen to generate our inline C++ documentation (`libopenage/`). We also use it for the Python code (`openage/`), but we should switch to [Sphinx](http://www.sphinx-doc.org/) for this.

To beautify our `doc/` folder, we could use [Sphinx](http://www.sphinx-doc.org/).

To link between both, there is [Breathe](https://breathe.readthedocs.io/en/latest/).

Then we would have a nice and one-for-all documentation by Sphinx: It natively support Python, the C++ parsing is still done by Doxygen which would be nicely integrated via breathe.

data.title: Windows installer package
data.body:
Summary of the changes:
- Install all files using relative path (CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX is different for packaging).
- `include(CPack)` with appropriate values to get a skeleton installer.
- For MSVC specifically,
  - copy the dll dependencies of libopenage. See `ResolveDependencies.cmake`.
  - embed DejaVu font with conf files. See `EmbedFont.cmake`.
  - embed python interpreter. See `EmbedPython.cmake`.
  - copy the required python modules. See `copy_modules.py`.
  - copy `REQUIRED_UTILITIES`, viz. opusenc.exe.
  - include `openage.bat` to start the appropriate executable.

[Updates]
- Replace `exit` with (`import sys`, and) `sys.exit` in all python code.
- Add documentation for packaging on Windows.

Next steps (possibly subsequent PR):
- Customize the installer (icons, images, etc.)
- Customize the installation
  - launch shortcuts with appropriate icons.
  - choose embedded python or use existing installation.
- ~Detect AoE installation or input directory at install time.~

data.title: doc: Selection mechanics
data.body: Some stuff about selecting units that seems obvious at first, but was actually a bit more complex.

data.title: Get more tests to pass on Windows
data.body:
[Reverted in favor of #895] ~Fixes #876 - verified on Windows (NTFS).~
A few modifications to assertions in existing tests to accommodate MSVC's behavior.

data.title: fslike: fix caseignoringdir-test for caseignoring filesystems
data.body:
Fixes #876.
If we're on a caseignoring filesystem already, we can't assume that other-case files aren't found.

data.title: convert: introduce interactive conversion shell
data.body:
Fixes #853.

Also fixes a bug introduced by cdd3bf61adc84239a59925a823411edcbc13e1b8, which didn't update the `get_palette` call of the interactive browser.

data.title: Use directly libpng to create screenshots.
data.body:
\<rant\> libpng's doc is ugly! the api isn't really documented. there is only a list of all functions and a walkthrough. but I miss an explanation for every function, what it does, what the arguments are and what is returned. \</rant\>
this uses directly libpng to create the screenshot. it strips the alpha channel and does the encoding in another thread. (well, when I'm finished)

note to self: I need to learn how to use shared_ptr and unique_ptr. somehow I get unreadable build errors, when I try to use them...

data.title: Update C-style cast to static_cast in program.cpp
data.body: Just a simple style tweak.

data.title: buildsystem: add convenience options for using ccache
data.body:
Speeds up some compilations if used.

The cache will be in `~/.cache/ccache` by default.

`ccache -s` will show you statistics. which you can `watch -n1` during builds :)
